text: Patient: …you had another patient that his insurance wouldn’t cover it until… Doctor: It’s the same thing. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Until you actually have a problem and then they go oh look he’s got a problem, okay we’ll give it to you now. I know. Patient: That’s terrible. Doctor: It’s terrible. So… Family Member: Why are they not approving the chemo? Doctor: I have no clue. They don’t have to give a reason remember? They just say denied so then we’re like we don’t understand and then you play the round robin, you know talk to that person, talk to that person, at some point it’s gonna have to be talk to the Medical Director and I’m gonna be like this ain’t complicated. I would image it has probably a lot to do with you were on a trial and now you’re not and they’re behind right. So we’re moving at real time speed… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And stuff that they have is like always behind so you know there isn’t a – there isn’t a visit right now until right now for us to say well you’re done with that study, you’re now getting Taxotere just like a regular non-study patient and I’m sure they haven’t processes that in their head. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they go everything by notes. So everything for you has been on, on, on – oh we’re now going to get radiation,

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we call that micro metastatic cancer. Patient: All right. Doctor: Has spread somewhere else, but it’s so tiny, microscopic that we cannot find it on the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And in the past we did have two areas that lit up on the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: We had the bone scan and you had both of those areas radiated at the same time as getting the hormone therapy. Patient: Correct. Right. Doctor: So it’s possible that those would not be visible at this time. Or it’s possible that they still might be visible and it’s also possible that new areas you know might have popped up somewhere else in different bones or different areas like lymph nodes which were not there before. So it’s very important you know once the PSA reaches one that we basically establish what the extent of your cancer is at that point in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, um, the standard recommendation for you at that point would be to go back uh on a hormone therapy. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment Doctor: I think there's like a good at least two to three week washout you know we got to let that one get out of your system. Doctor: -that's not what we want. Patient: Do I throw away? Doctor: No, no no no. Don't go throw anything. text: Patient: Well, I have some relatives in Germany. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And, uh- Family Member: Yeah. If they’re still there. (Laughter) Patient: Pardon? Family Member: I said if they’re still there because-. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. That’s a good point. Right. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, I think if you want to explore that, my feeling would be if you can get it on the study, well and good. If not, you should explore if you can go and, you know, I don’t know what it costs there, and, you know, what you have to pay. Family Member: If you can get on, on the study, which would involve the scan, doing the scan? Doctor: Doing the scan first. Family Member: Yeah. Of course. Doctor: But even there, they would do the scan first, because if it’s not going to help you, they’re not going to push you to get the treatment that’s not going to work.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
